## The Paris Climate Agreement

:::{.incremental}

- Limit "the increase in global average temperature to well below 2° C above pre-industrial levels"
  - Dangerous and cascading effects beyond this threshold

- "to limit the temperature increase to 1.5° C above pre-industrial levels" 
  - To avoid the most drastic and devastating impacts 

:::

## IPCC reporting

:::{.incremental}
- [**"More likely than not"**]{.underline} that we will reach the 1.5° C threshold by 2040

- In addition to drastic emissions reductions - most successful pathways rely on CO₂ removal technology (CDR)
:::

::: footer
IPCC - Climate Change 2023: Synthesis Report - https://doi.org/10.59327/ipcc/ar6-9789291691647.001
:::

## How do we make this information actionable?

## Forest biomass maps

::: {.incremental}

- Provide information at scales relevant to decision-making and management
  
  - Individual forests, stands, and ownership parcels
  
- NYS can use this data to:

  - Identify stocks that should be protected

  - Prioritize areas for management

  - Quantify management outcomes

  - More precisely identify spatiotemporal patterns and drivers of change

:::

## Aboveground biomass -> carbon

- ~50% of tree biomass is carbon

- Root-to-shoot ratios to convert aboveground biomass to belowground biomass

## Stock-change methods and carbon accounting

::: {.incremental}

::: columns

::: {.column width="50%"}

- Need repeated measurements / estimates / inventories

- Differences between time 1 and time 2

- Net fluxes

  - Positive differences (growth) = removals from the atmosphere

  - Negative differences (disturbance) = emissions to the atmosphere

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}

![](figures/stock_change.png){width=100% fig-align='center'}

  - Describes our maps in aggregate (NYS)

  - How precise are our predictions?
  
  - Describes arbitrary map sub-regions

## Aggregation to reduce uncertainty{.smaller}

:::{.incremental}

::: columns

:::{.column width='30%'}

- Individual pixel predictions are highly variable

- Pixels are not ecologically or practically meaningful

- Aggregating smooths out variation

- Pixel-level errors may cancel out

- The degree to which they cancel out depends on spatial correlation

## Upshot of accuracy and uncertainty

:::{.incremental}

- Accuracy assessment describes our maps in aggregate (all of NYS)
  - Compare to FIA across a range of scales 

- Uncertainty can describe arbitrary map sub-regions

  - Help map users make decisions

  - Identify a range of estimates/outcomes

  - Attributing sources of uncertainty -> identify areas for improvement
  
- Room for improvement
  - New satellites and sensors
  - More data to collect

:::
